title: 106_s382
content: The Act may be cited as the "Minuteman Missile National Historic Site Establishment Act of 1999". Congress finds that the Minuteman II intercontinental ballistic missile launch control facility and launch facility known as "Delta 1" and "Delta 9" are significant examples of American history during the Cold War. These facilities symbolize the dedication of Air Force missileers stationed in remote locations, providing a unique opportunity to illustrate the history of the Cold War and ICBM development. The National Park System lacks a unit specifically commemorating the Cold War. The Minuteman II missile defense system facilities symbolize American history during the Cold War and the dedication of Air Force missileers. The Act aims to preserve and interpret these structures, highlighting their role in America's strategic commitment to world peace and the broader context of the Cold War. This initiative complements existing interpretive programs related to the Minuteman II system offered by the South Dakota Air Force. The Act aims to preserve and interpret the Minuteman II missile defense system facilities, highlighting their role in America's strategic commitment to world peace and the Cold War. It complements interpretive programs offered by the South Dakota Air and Space Museum. The Minuteman Missile National Historic Site is established to preserve and interpret the Minuteman II missile defense system facilities, showcasing their significance in America's strategic commitment to world peace and the Cold War. The Minuteman Missile National Historic Site in South Dakota is established as part of the National Park System, consisting of the Minuteman II ICBM launch control facilities. The site includes the Delta 1 and Delta 9 Launch Control Facilities. The Minuteman Missile National Historic Site in South Dakota includes the Delta 1 and Delta 9 Launch Control Facilities. The Secretary of the Interior is authorized to make minor boundary adjustments, and the site shall be administered in accordance with relevant laws. The Secretary administers the historic site in compliance with relevant laws and may consult with other agencies. Cooperative agreements are allowed. The Secretary may acquire land within the historic site boundaries through various means and prohibited acquisitions include contaminated land. The Secretary can acquire land within the historic site boundaries through donation, purchase, or exchange from another Federal agency. Prohibited acquisitions include contaminated land and land owned by the State of South Dakota. The Secretary can acquire land within the historic site boundaries through donation, purchase, or exchange from another Federal agency. Prohibited acquisitions include contaminated land and land owned by the State of South Dakota. The Secretary may acquire South Dakota land only by donation or exchange. A general management plan must be prepared within 3 years, including an evaluation of appropriate locations for visitor facilities and administrative sites. The plan for the historic site includes evaluating locations for visitor facilities and administrative sites within specified areas. The site boundary will be modified to include the selected location. Coordination with Badlands National Park for administrative functions is also considered. Authorization of appropriations is granted for carrying out the Act, including transferring Air Force funds for the maintenance and operation of a historic site. The Legacy Resource Management Program's funds for resource preservation and treaty compliance remain unaffected. The curr_chunk is about the roles of the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Vice President of the United States as President of the Senate.
